awd_titl_txt: REU Site: CAT Vehicle: The Cognitive and Autonomous Test Vehicle
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is a renewal of a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Arizona. The goal of the project is to empower students to engage with the myriad applications that are related to autonomous ground vehicles and machine learning. The approach is the application of model-based design approaches that raise the level of abstraction to permit the safe operation of a full-sized robotic vehicle testbed. The 10-week Site will provide 10 NSF-funded undergraduate students with immersive research experiences, sitting side-by-side with graduate researchers and working on one of the most compelling, and complex applications of today: autonomous systems. A diverse group of students recruited nationwide will produce an exciting final demonstration of their research.

A full-size robotic car will be paired with core research in machine learning, made possible with data gathered with automotive sensors. These themes provide a context in which participants will explore research in model-based design for cyber-physical systems, machine learning, human-in-the-loop systems, control, and autonomous systems. Participants will use a spiral development process, where new project requirements are added after previous requirements are verified, as part of the safety procedures for the full-sized vehicle testbed. Through these process structures, participants will leave behind datasets, software, and video demonstrations of their projects. This project will improve the reproducibility of the work and provide records of the experience to benefit the state-of-the-art, and artifacts that demonstrate the potential that model-based approaches can empower undergraduate researchers in discovery.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The Cognitive and Autonomous Test Vehicle REU site engaged undergraduate students in research projects on autonomous ground vehicles, controls, communications, vehicular security, machine learning, and algorithms. The students followed a rigorous 10-week program that involved attending short technical courses, conducting research in the areas related to the site, preparing for graduate school, and developing their presentation and technical writing skills. The students worked side-by-side with graduate mentors and faculty advisors on contemporary problems in computer science and engineering. The program fostered intellectual creativity, engaged students in hands-on experiences with societal-scale applications, and promoted individual confidence, team camaraderie, and interdisciplinary collaboration. 

The REU site hosted 32 students in total.  Thirteen students were women, 40.6%. Six students identified as first generation, 18.8%. Six students identified as an underrepresented ethnic/racial minority population, 18.8%, identifying as Hispanic and or African American. Students were enrolled in diverse colleges and universities, representing a range of majors including computer science, electrical and computer engineering, mathematics, and mechanical engineering. Upon the program completion, the students reported high confidence in following general research processes and methods, conducting scientific presentations and literature reviews, translating real-world problems into research questions, and developing skills that will help with graduate school. They also reported significant gains in skills in electrical engineering, software engineering, computerengineering, and other CAT vehicle-related areas.

Sample outcomes from the student projects include novel machine-learning-based computer vision algorithms for vehicular applications, such as object detection and classification, object tracking, and lane segmentation; new mechanisms for binding the digital identity of vehicles with their physical attributes such as their physical trajectory; a trust framework for securing navigation messages from insider spoofing attacks and exercising adaptive control based on trust levels; continuous trust renewal mechanisms to mitigate attacks through compromised digital credentials; new physical access control models for vehicular platoons; generative modeling of driving profiles; real-time traffic light identification mechanisms, and safer adaptive cruise control algorithms for traffic wave dampening. The project outcomes were disseminated through publications in peer-reviewed conferences, presentations in research symposia, technical reports, and publicly available project narration videos. 


Last Modified: 07/17/2024
Modified by: Loukas Lazos
